text: today on the caucus Jeff Zeleny on the
political positioning as debt
negotiations become increasingly content
hello everybody also James traube
reflects on traveling with John Kerry
for his magazine profile of the
Massachusetts senator i am still pushing
for us to achieve a big deal but what I
also said to the group with is if we
can't do the biggest deal possible then
let's still be ambitious the week ended
with yet one more set of dueling press
conferences President Obama's at the
White House the house Republican leaders
are on Capitol Hill and they're ending
the week probably farther apart than
they were we can go I think it'd be no
tax hikes because tax hikes destroy jobs
as these talks head into the weekend one
thing that's clear is that both sides
are leaving open the option of siting on
to the so-called McConnell plan it's the
agreement put forward by senator Mitch
McConnell the Republican leader it
wouldn't create a long-term strategy but
it would solve things in a short term
that is not my preferable option though
I just want to be clear I think about
this like a layer cake you know you can
do the bare minimum and then you can
make some progressively harder decisions
to solve the problem more and more so
one thing I thought was interesting
today is President Obama his audience
was more than ever before the voters out
there the independent voters who may be
watching this what the American people
are paying attention to is who seems to
be trying to get something done and who
seems to be just posturing and trying to
score political points and I think it's
going to be in the interests of
everybody who wants to continue to serve
in this town to make sure that they are
on the right side of that impression but
on the other side Republicans believe
that they were elected they were sent to
Washington who last fall with the new
majority to hold down taxes we want to
be able to go home to the people that
elected us and show them that we're not
going to allow this kind of spending to
continue it's a different interpretation
of the same electorate of course
President Obama is looking for those
independent voters and Republicans are
looking at their at their core group of
supporters in their base so both sides
are claiming that they have sort of have
the will of the people behind them of
course that's not quite true those
independent voters who actually decide
things in 2012 our front and center in
this president's mind at least the
president is absolutely looking for the
high ground here and it looks like he
may have it as the week comes to an end
at least in the rhetoric side of things
but again on the substance side of
things it sure does not look like
they're much closer to a deal I always
have hope don't you remember my campaign
John Kerry wanted to be Secretary of
State but that job went to Hillary
Clinton he's carved out an important
role in President Obama's foreign policy
anyway James trout profiles him in this
week's magazine my original interest in
Kerry is when I realized that he had
become a kind of diplomatic agent of the
Obama administration in a way that I had
never heard of anybody doing the premise
was can I travel with you and see you do
what you do and he said yes and it was
only later that I was told by some of
his aides he had never said yes to that
question before I really concluded that
the most important thing was Afghanistan
Afghanistan and Pakistan and so I waited
for him to go there and i kind of got
kept getting put off and put off and put
off by the time he had scheduled the
trip Osama bin Laden had been killed
I've traveled with Vice President Biden
I travel with the UN secretary-general
it's always hard when you are traveling
with the big guy right because if you
travel inside a bubble the good thing
about Kerry is that he hates to have a
big entourage she travels by himself
typically when he goes somewhere he has
one aide that's it he's very
quiet and he's very interrogative with
the people he chose to talk to he
genuinely wanted to see the world as
they see it Carrie is a consensus
seeking person which is a good thing
diplomatically good thing in terms of
his role as a senator it's a limitation
maybe when you were trying to think
about a hard question and you don't want
to stray too far away from what you
understand to be mainstream opinion i
think in a situation like Afghanistan
and Pakistan were the facts have changed
so much I don't know whether he's fully
acknowledged the failure of the effort
and has fully allowed himself to
consider whether there should be a big
big change supposed to a wheel slope
step change but I saw a person who was
who was comfortable and who was really
enjoying himself and it was completely
into the moment I mean totally totally
focus he didn't want to be anywhere else
except where he was at the same time
he's an ambitious person you don't run
for president and almost win if you're
not an ambitious person he wanted to be
Secretary of State in 2009 and he'd like
to be Secretary of State in 2012 or 2013
it is a real ambition that he has I also
think if it doesn't happen and he
continues as chairman of Senate Foreign
Relations that's okay too
you
